titleStmt.title: Susan H. Parker to James F. Robinson
CWG8788

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, James F. Robinson: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons, Remissions, and Respites, 1862-1863

body.p: To his Excellency, Jas F. Robinson, Governor of Kentucky
Your Petitioner Susan Parker, Respectfully asks permission to represent to your Excellency in candor and truth the circumstances impelling her to beg the exercise of your Clemency on her behalf,

That she is a citizen of Frankfort and owner of the little home where she resides, having purchased the lot & improved the same, that during the winter of 1861 &c. she rented that portion of her house built & designed for a store room, to one Wm Watkins, that he occupied the same as his own property during his lease that she exercised no control or ownership over it or its management during the time whatever.

That subsequently, say at the June term of the Circuit Court for Franklin County, she together with said Watkins was fined the sum of sixty dollars each for keeping a tipling House & Executive allowed to go.

She disclaims any knowledge that sd Watkins was dealing unlawfully in liquor, or any thing else, and although notified of the time & trial she did not attend, not really knowing when or how to act in the premises, That she finds hereself wholly unable to pay the fine or any part thereof, and most earnestly begs that the same be remitted
Sworn to by Susan Parker before one Police Judge of this City of Frankfort this 18" Day of Apl 1863
John R. Graham P J C F

Before Wm Watkins left for the Army he came to me and requested me to go with him to see Mrs. Parker as he wished to have some conversation with her in the presence of a witness -- during the conversation said Watkins said that Mrs Parker Knew nothing of his having liquor in that part of the house rented by him from her and he would make oath to the fact in Court. He also stated that he was the guilty party and not Mrs Parker.

John W. Pruett
G N Owen
Jno N Crutcher
G W Gwin
We the undersigned unite in the subjoined petition

John M Harlan
James Harlan Jr
John R Graham
W M Gray
J. M. Mills
R. Runyan.

Franklin Cir. Ct
$60 } Tipling
Susan Parker
Remission Issd
Apr 21st 1863
The within fine remitted
J F Robinson
